Estonian citizens and residents are allowed into the country regardless of whether they are symptomatic or not.  Entry into Estonia for the purposes of work, studying, tourism, sports etc is also allowed for the citizens of other countries (both European Union and third countriesâ). The citizens of third countries have to have a valid Schengen visa in order to be able to enter the country.  In certain cases, including those without vaccination certificate, recovery certificate, or a negative COVID-19 test, it is obligatory to stay in self-isolation after entering the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403110543/https://kriis.ee/en/travelling-crossing-state-border/travelling-estonia/coming-estonia  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403105151/https://www.kriis.ee/en/covid-crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions#entry

In order to reduce the risk of people falling ill at work and the deductible of employees, and thereby limit the spread of COVID-19, the procedure for reimbursing sick leaves was temporarily changed from 01.01.2021. The employee's deductible is the first day of illness, the employer pays the benefit from the second to the fifth day and the health insurance fund pays the benefit from the sixth day. This compensation procedure will continue in 2022.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220403112137/https://kriis.ee/en/work-life-and-being-away-work/employee/sick-days-certificates-care-leave  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403112132/https://haigekassa.ee/inimesele/haigekassa-huvitised/haigushuvitis-01012021-31122022

The requirements for entry into Finland include the following:   - a certificate of a full approved COVID-19 vaccination series, OR  - a certificate of having had the COVID-19 disease and one approved COVID-19 vaccine, OR  - an EU Digital COVID Certificate for a COVID-19 disease had less than six months ago, AND  - a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken no earlier than 48 hours before arrival in Finland.    These requirements apply to those born in or before 2006. They however do not apply to citizens of Finland, those with permanent residence in Finland or persons travelling for essential reasons. Those who do not meet the requirement are required to have a mandatory covid test.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220106182331/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

The requirements for entry into Finland include the following and they apply to foreigners entering Finland from outside of the EU and Schengen area: :   - a certificate of a full approved COVID-19 vaccination series, OR  - a certificate of having had the COVID-19 disease and one approved COVID-19 vaccine, OR  - an EU Digital COVID Certificate for a COVID-19 disease had less than six months ago, AND  - a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken no earlier than 48 hours before arrival in Finland.    These requirements apply to those born in or before 2006. They however do not apply to citizens of Finland, those with permanent residence in Finland or persons travelling for essential reasons. Those who do not meet the requirement are required to have a mandatory covid test.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220409125623/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

Vaccination is universally available to people aged 5 and over, with one parent's permission required for children aged between 5 and 11.     Vaccination boosters are available to all people aged 12 and over from three months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     Vaccination is mandatory for all staff of medical and medico-social institutions (including administrative staff), supporting services, and those who work in contact with frail people.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071212/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

No change in policy, in addition to policies affecting the general population it remains a requirement that all people working with elderly people are fully vaccinated as a condition of employment. The vaccine pass remains mandatory to access elderly home care centres.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071212/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

It is no longer a free public service to get tested for COVID-19. From the 1st March 2022 it is no longer possible til book a COVID-19 PCR-test from the hospital system.  Looking forward, people who need a PCR-test from the hospital system will be informed by a relevant healthcare professional.  People who need a PCR-test for other reasons, for example in connection with travel on a vacation or for work abroad, need to contact a private laboratory.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220302043144/https://korona.fo/current-recommendations?_l=en

It is no longer a recommendation that people infected with COVID-19 shall quarantine.  Each one of us is individually responsible for whether we are exposing others to infection. Keeping a distance and hygiene is the best protection against infection.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220302043144/https://korona.fo/current-recommendations?_l=en

Any citizen/resident of a foreign country may enter Georgia through air, land or marine borders from March 1, 2022 if fully vaccinated. Unvaccinated individuals needs to present a PCR test valid for 72 hours (without an obligation of getting re-tested with PCR on the third day); So-called country locks are vanishing.  https://archive.ph/jEsvY

All citizens of foreign countries will be admitted to Georgia via air, land, and marine borders provided they are fully vaccinated (two full doses, except only one is required for Johnson & Johnson) or have a negative PCR test result (administered 72 hours or less before arrival in Georgia).  There is no obligation to self isolate, or for unvaccinated individuals to get re-tested on the third day after arrival, or to complete an application form. More information is available here.  Travelers under the age of 10 are exempt from the obligation to provide a vaccination certificate or negative PCR test.  https://archive.ph/aV68A

All family members living with the coronavirus positive person should stay in isolation. If in contact, Move to isolation (may be administered at home or a respective isolation hotel) during 5 days from the most recent contact. Besides, you are strictly recommended to wear a facemask for the following 6-12 days. Observe your health condition and if you experience symptoms characteristic to COVID-19, reach out to the emergency hotline at 112 or your GP, who will redirect you for testing to start with.  https://archive.ph/wUkAD

Guidelines for primary schools, day care institutions and recreational activities:  -In the case of infection at schools and institutions etc., it will most often be other contacts that are of concern.  -Children, who are other contacts to an infected person (child or employee) in a day-care nursery etc., in school (including boarding schools and private schools) or in connection with recreational activities, must follow the recommendations for other contacts. Learn more in the section If you are an other contact.  -However, roommates at boarding schools etc., must follow the guidelines for close contacts.  Last updated Wednesday 9. february  https://web.archive.org/web/20220329043534/https://corona.nun.gl/en/at-the-workplace/guidelines-for-primary-schools-day-care-and-after-school-activities/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.    Requirements to enter Greenland by air or sea:  People who are 12 years old or older must be able to document one of the following things in order to enter Greenland by air or sea:  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must document this with a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency. You can download your certificate of residence at sullissivik.gl.  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must be able to document that you have a job or a home in Greenland. For example, you can use a rental contract, a contract of employment or a letter from your coming employer as proof.  -If you are not a resident of Greenland you must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 and able to provide documentation proving this.  -You are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated. Only vaccines approved by EMA are accepted.  -Furthermore, you must live up to the rules on use of face masks during travel to Greenland.  Last updated Wednesday 2. march  https://web.archive.org/web/20220303195718/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Last updated Wednesday 2. march  https://web.archive.org/web/20220411234343/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

If you test positive:  Test result  -If your test result is positive, it means you are infected with the coronavirus.  -If your result from a PCR-test is positive, you will receive your test result via SMS. You are responsible for contacting your close contacts. Read more about the definition of a close contact.  -If you have taken an antigen test (home test) which shows a positive result, you should consider yourself infected with COVID-19. You must follow the same guidelines, but you will not be contacted by the health department / corona secretariat.  Last updated Wednesday 9. february  https://web.archive.org/web/20220215024602/https://corona.nun.gl/en/infection-and-symptoms/if-you-test-positive/

Good advice for people at a higher risk:  -In general, if you are someone who is at a higher risk, you can continue to do the things you did before the COVID-19 pandemic, e.g. go to work, participate in leisure activities and take care of your grandchildren.  -If before the COVID-19 pandemic, you had to follow special precautions in your daily life to avoid being infected with an infectious disease, e.g. you have a special condition and are immunocompromised, you should continue to follow those precautions.    The National Board of Health in Greenland (âLandslÃ¦geembedetâ) recommends the following for persons who are at a higher risk:  -Get re-vaccinated  -Follow the recommendations from the Office of the Medical Director of Health and ask others to be mindful  -Avoid large events and gatherings of people where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider using a face mask in public spaces where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider talking with your workplace about how to ensure that you can go to work safely    The older you are â the more and more serious chronic diseases have â the more attention you need to pay to following the recommendations. You must naturally take your quality of life into consideration, when you place limits on your life.  *Risk groups and highly vulnerable people  Last updated Friday 4. february  https://web.archive.org/web/20220329051350/https://corona.nun.gl/en/information-about-covid-19/

No policy change.  Physical distance, hygiene, and other preventative measures in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403223541/https://www.koronavirus.hr/uploads/Upute_za_sprjecavanje_i_suzbijanje_epidemije_bolesti_COVID_19_vezano_uz_rad_predskolskih_ustanova_osnovnih_i_srednjih_skola_u_skolskoj_godini_2021_2022_3_75c63541db.pdf

No policy change.  In order to adapt as much as possible to the new conditions, employers are advised to organize, wherever possible, work from home or work in shifts, in order to avoid interfering with workers. For the protection of one's own, but also the health of others, it is recommended that all business trips be postponed and that meetings be held online. Jobs related to the health care system also have specially prescribed measures that employees must adhere to so that the system itself is not overloaded.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403224542/https://koronavirus.hr/o-poslu/46

Professional artistic performances, cultural programs and events attended only by persons (visitors, performers and staff) holding an EU digital COVID certificate of vaccination, testing and / or recovery from COVID-19 are exempt from all restrictions of this recommendation - including the obligation to wear masks, physical distances, number of persons present, etc. Also, if all contractors have an EU digital COVID certificate, they are exempt from all anti-epidemic measures.    It is mandatory to use a face mask indoors and when it is not possible to maintain a physical distance of at least 1.5 m outdoors. The obligation to use the mask does not apply to visitors during the consumption of food and beverages, nor to contractors during the performance.    It is obligatory to adhere to the measure of physical distancing which avoids close personal contact at a distance of at least 1.5 meters outdoors and 2 meters indoors. It is not necessary for people living in a joint household to maintain the prescribed distance. The distance between the visitor and the performer on stage must be at least 4 meters.     The physical distance between visitors during the program, the organizer must provide seats 1.5 meters apart  Exceptionally, when holding performances, cultural programs and low-risk events, the physical distance between visitors from 1 seat is allowed, with the obligatory wearing of masks during the program. The restriction does not apply to visitors living in the same household. Low-risk programs are programs with exclusively seating places that do not involve interaction with the audience and active engagement of the audience such as singing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403225317/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-svakodnevnom-zivotu/preporuke-za-sprjecavanje-zaraze-covid-19-tijekom-odrzavanja-profesionalnih-umjetnickih-izvedbi-kulturnih-programa-i-manifestacija/740

Indoor public gatherings are limited to 100 people. No limitation if everyone attending has a digital COVID-19 certificate.  Outdoor public gatherings are limited to no more than 200 people. No limitation if everyone attending has a digital COVID-19 certificate.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No policy change.  Are commercial flights operating? Yes  Is public transportation operating? Yes  Wearing protective masks is mandatory?throughout?the country?in public transportation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No stay at home requirements.

No restrictions on movements.    Is a curfew in place? No  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No policy change.  A negative viral test result: PCR not older than 72 hours or rapid antigen test (list of acceptable antigen tests) not older than 48 hours (counting from the time of taking the test to arriving at the border crossing point).  A certificate showing they have received two doses of vaccine used in the EU Member States or vaccines approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since receiving the second dose of the vaccine, or a certificate showing they have received a single doze of the vaccine if the vaccine is administered in a single doze not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since the single doze, or a certificate that they have received the booster doze of the vaccine.  A certificate showing that they have recovered from COVID-19 and have received one dose of vaccine used in EU Member States or a vaccine approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use, provided that 14 days have passed since they received the single dose within eight months from contracting the disease, provided that the vaccine was administered less than 270 days from their arrival at the border crossing point.  A positive PCR test result or rapid antigen test result, confirming that the holder recovered from the SARS-CoV-2 virus infection, which was performed in the previous 180 days, and which is older than 11 days from the date of arrival at the border crossing point, or a medical certificate of recovery.  Perform PCR testing or rapid antigen testing immediately upon arrival to Croatia (at the travelerâs own expense), with the obligation to stay in self-isolation until receiving a negative test result. If testing cannot be performed, travelers must self-isolate for a period of 10 days.  Travelers can facilitate faster processing at the Croatian border by completing the Enter Croatia web form and uploading their information and attachments ahead of their arrival.  Tourists are also required to show the proof of booked or paid accommodation or ownership of a home or a vessel when entering Croatia.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No evidence of income support.
No evidence of debt/contract relief.
Updates and recommendations consistently posted online.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403232111/https://www.koronavirus.hr/

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Croatia? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within one calendar day? Yes  A test can be arranged at the following locations:?COVID-19 Testing Locations in Croatia.  The cost of a local test (rapid antigen test or a PCR test) ranges from $40 to $150 or more, depending upon the location, and the result can be expected between 1-48 hours depending upon the type of the test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Mobile app is available for contact tracing but no evidence of 'on-the-ground' contact tracing. I believe previous coding has relied on the mobile app availability as evidence of contact tracing.

Wearing protective masks is mandatory?in all closed spaces throughout?the country. Masks are also mandatory in open spaces where a physical distance of at least 1.5 meters cannot be maintained.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Has the government of Croatia approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes  Are vaccines available in Croatia for U.S. citizens to receive? Yes  Which vaccines are available in Croatia? PfizerâBioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson.  According to the Croatian Institute for Public Health, foreigners with temporary or permanent residency in Croatia can register for the COVID-19 vaccine through their local healthcare provider.  If you have an OIB (Croatian Personal Identification Number) and a local health insurance plan, you may visit https://cijepise.zdravlje.hr/ to register to get vaccinated.  If you do not have a local health insurance plan, you may visit the following Croatian Institute of Public Health website for the contact details of the county public health institutes to register by phone.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Updated March 17: New measures have been announced to address the elderly population, which is also the most vulnerable. Follow these pages, we will publish them as soon as they are official.    The most effective general prevention measures:  frequent hand hygiene with products containing 70% alcohol: rub your hands if your hands are invisibly dirty or wash with soap and water if your hands are dirty for about 20 seconds  avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth  maintain air hygiene by coughing or sneezing into a bent elbow or tissue and then immediately throw the tissue in the trash can with a lid  wearing a medical mask is mandatory if you have respiratory symptoms  after removing the mask from the face it is mandatory to carry out hand hygiene  maintaining a distance in social contact between persons of at least 1 meter if the person has any of the respiratory symptoms  maintain the hygiene of your living space by periodically wiping surfaces that are frequently touched with your hands with a surface disinfectant     https://web.archive.org/web/20220403232847/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-prevenciji/vazne-upute-za-starije-osobe-i-kronicne-bolesnike/51

the government is providing several significant subsidies:    parents received a family tax refund. In February 2022, parents raising a child were reimbursed for their income tax paid in 2021 up to the tax level of the average wage.  Retirees received a larger-than-ever pension premium  of HUF 80,000 in November and received a full refund  of their 13-month pension  in February 2022 .  Wage increases will continue: from January 2022 , the minimum wage will be HUF 200,000, the guaranteed minimum wage will be HUF 260,000,  thus the minimum wage will be higher from 2022 onwards.  Young people under the age of  25 will not have to pay income tax  from January 2022.  The credit moratorium was extended until June 30, 2022. Those who are expecting and raising a child, retirees, public employees can continue to take advantage of the opportunity, as can businesses and individuals whose incomes have fallen significantly from the previous year.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220411190956/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Protect yourself and others from COVID-19    If you have any symptoms of COVID-19, even mild ones, you should:    - self-isolate (stay in your room) until 48 hours after your symptoms are mostly or fully gone  - wear a face mask if you have to be around other people    Do these even if you completed your first round of COVID-19 vaccination, had a booster, or had COVID-19 in the past.    Do    - get a COVID-19 vaccine and booster dose when it's available to you    - keep at least 2 metres (around 6 feet) away from people you do not live with    - wash your hands properly and often    - wear a face mask in crowded places outdoors and when you move around in public indoor spaces    - cover coughs or sneezes with a tissue or your sleeve - put used tissues into a bin and wash your hands    - meet people outdoors where possible    - try to avoid crowded places where you cannot keep a distance from people - there's a greater risk of infection in crowded and enclosed places    - check that visitors to your home or workplace do not have symptoms of COVID-19, colds or flu    - let fresh air into your home by opening windows, doors and air vents as much as possible when you have visitors    - clean objects and surfaces that other people touch      Don't    - do not touch your eyes, nose or mouth if your hands are not clean    - do not share objects that touch your mouth, for example, bottles or cups    - do not shake hands or make close contact with other people, if possible    - do not wear gloves instead of washing your hands - your hands can get contaminated when you take them off    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319141023/https://www2.hse.ie/conditions/covid19/preventing-the-spread/protect-yourself-and-others/

11th April 2022, Getting a booster dose    To get your first booster dose, you must be aged 12 or older.    12 to 15 year olds must attend their booster appointment with a parent or legal guardian. A parent or legal guardian will need to give consent for their child's vaccination.    Do not book an appointment for a second booster dose yet. These will be available soon for:    people over 65  people over 12 with a weak immune system  How long to wait before getting your first booster    After your first round of COVID-19 vaccination, you need to wait:    3 months (at least 90 days) if you are 16 or older  6 months (at least 182 days) if you are aged 12 to 15  You will not get your booster dose if the minimum interval has not passed on the day of your appointment.    If you had COVID-19 since you were vaccinated, you should get your booster dose at least:    3 months after your positive test result or when symptoms started if you are 16 or older  6 months after your positive test result or when symptoms started if you are aged 12 to 15  If you had an additional dose because you have a weak immune system, you can get your booster at least 3 months after your additional dose if you are 12 or older.    Vaccines:    Pfizer/BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine  Moderna/Spikevax COVID-19 vaccine  Novavax COVID-19 vaccine  Janssen COVID-19 vaccine  AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine (not currently available)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220412001307/https://covid19booster.healthservice.ie/hse-self-referral/?flow=booster

Green passes are required only for university students: for university students that are non-vaccinated, there is a requirement to show a negative-test or a certification that they recently recovered from Covid. For unvaccinated university students school is otherwise closed.  For vaccinated students masks and social distancing (desks/seats 1m apart) are still required.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315122727/https://www.governo.it/sites/governo.it/files/documenti/documenti/Notizie-allegati/tabella_attivita_consentite.pdf

A Super Green pass is mandatory to all workers 50+ and for some additional workers categories, irrespective of age. Such workplaces are virtually closed for those who are not vaccinated or recently recovered from Covid.  All other workers still need a Green Pass.  In all cases, masks and social distancing still are enforced at work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315122727/https://www.governo.it/sites/governo.it/files/documenti/documenti/Notizie-allegati/tabella_attivita_consentite.pdf

In order to enter a non-essential business, a green pass or super green pass is required.  A Super Green pass is mandatory to all workers 50+ and for some additional workers categories, irrespective of age. Such workplaces are virtually closed for those who are not vaccinated or recently recovered from Covid.  All other workers still need a Green Pass.  In all cases, masks and social distancing still are enforced at work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320203534/https://www.governo.it/sites/governo.it/files/documenti/documenti/Notizie-allegati/tabella_attivita_consentite.pdf

From March 1st almost all travel restrictions have been removed. The only restrictions still in place are to show a "green pass equivalent" certificate (so not a vaccine mandate).  Vaccinated people therefore just need to show their vaccination status, unvaccinated people need to show a negative test or proof or recent recovery from Covid. In case a proof of vaccination or recent recovery cannot be provided they will need to quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220317090845/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto  https://web.archive.org/web/20220316225911/https://www.esteri.it/it/ministero/normativaonline/focus-cittadini-italiani-in-rientro-dall-estero-e-cittadini-stranieri-in-italia/

Vaccine mandates are in place for:  - all school & university personnel (including teachers)  - everyone 50+ (from Jan 8th)  - healthcare workers (everyone working in healthcare facilities, so this is not limited to nurses and doctors)  - long term care facilities personnel  - military personnel, law enforcement and public rescue personnel, jail guards and public cybersecurity personnel (as they are still military personnel)    It is clearly stated at the following link that the vaccine mandate is for everyone 50+, not just workers. At the same link, you can find a detailed list of the categories for which a mandate is in place: https://web.archive.org/web/20220311173308/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5452&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto    The mandate is **NOT** in place for taxi drivers, private security guards or government officials. For such categories the general green pass requirement is in place (which is not a vaccine mandate)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211222164937/https://www.fiscoetasse.com/rassegna-stampa/31598-obbligo-vaccinale-e-terza-dose-le-nuove-categorie-interessate-dal-1512.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211214656/https://www.ipsoa.it/documents/impresa/contratti-dimpresa/quotidiano/2022/01/08/covid-19-vigore-8-gennaio-obbligo-vaccinale-cinquantenni

No changes found    Archive Link   https://web.archive.org/web/20220405041414/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/kazakhstan-authorities-amend-covid-19-related-domestic-measures-as-of-march-4-update-53
Quote "Red: movement restricted to self-isolation regime"    Archive Link   https://web.archive.org/web/20220404122416/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Quote: "Is a curfew in place?  No.    Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  Yes, in some cases.  As of May 11, 2021, the Government of Kazakhstan began prohibiting people who accompany departing travelers or meet arriving passengers from entering airports and rail stations in regions in high risk âRed Zones.â An exception exists for airports and rail stations participating in the âAshyqâ application system (please see further information on âAshyqâ in the Quarantine Information paragraph below).  Kazakhstanâs regions are empowered to take additional measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 as necessary, including erecting checkpoints to limit travel in and out of cities and oblasts.  Before pursuing domestic travel in Kazakhstan, we urge you to research whether checkpoints might be in place that could restrict your ability to travel. "    Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220404122416/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Quote: "To enter Kazakhstan, international arrivals generally must provide evidence of a negative result from a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival. Travelers with a valid vaccination certificate are exempt from the testing requirement. This pre-travel testing requirement does not apply to children under five years of age, Kazakhstani government delegations, and cabin crew."    Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220405041414/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/kazakhstan-authorities-amend-covid-19-related-domestic-measures-as-of-march-4-update-53  ___________________________________________  Quote: "The Government of Kazakhstan requires foreign travelers arriving in Kazakhstan to provide a negative COVID-19 PCR test with results dated no more than three days prior to their entry to Kazakhstan.  If they are unable to provide negative PCR test results, they will be denied entry.  The following are exempt: children under age five, Kazakhstani Government delegations, and cabin crew.  In addition, each traveler must undergo a temperature check and fill out a questionnaire on prior travel, potential COVID-19 exposure, and contact information. "    Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220404122416/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Quote: "Masks Required: The Chief Sanitary Doctor of Kazakhstan has recommended that masks be worn nationwide in public settings, including both indoor and outdoor spaces and on public transportation, but the requirement to wear masks in most places has been lifted. "    Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220404122416/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Quote: "Has the government of Kazakhstan approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes  Are vaccines available in Kazakhstan for U.S. citizens to receive?  Yes, for permanent residents (see below).  Which vaccines are available in Kazakhstan? Sputnik V, QazVac, CoronaVac, Sinopharm, and Pfizer. Pfizer vaccinations may not be available to non-Kazakhstani citizens. Please check with your local provider.  Foreigners who live and work in Kazakhstan and have permanent residence cards may receive COVID-19 vaccination free of charge just like Kazakhstani citizens.  "    Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220404122416/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Quote: "To enter Kazakhstan, international arrivals generally must provide evidence of a negative result from a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival. Travelers with a valid vaccination certificate are exempt from the testing requirement. This pre-travel testing requirement does not apply to children under five years of age, Kazakhstani government delegations, and cabin crew."    Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220405041414/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/kazakhstan-authorities-amend-covid-19-related-domestic-measures-as-of-march-4-update-53

Quote: "As of February 11, 2021, travelers may show their original vaccine card showing proof of vaccination against COVID-19 instead of a negative PCR test.  Travelers without vaccination or valid PCR results will be denied entry.  Children under age 5 are exempt from testing or vaccination entry requirements."  Archive link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220409222438/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No further updates found

Quote: "The Ministry of Health provides free testing only for symptomatic patients. For those requiring a negative PCR test for travel, state laboratories in Bishkek and Osh can provide tests for a fee (approximately $20), depending on testing capacity. Private COVID-19 testing is also available for a fee ($30) at Bonetsky Laboratory or Aqualab. Please contact the laboratory directly to inquire about their testing capacity. "    Archive link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220409222438/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No further updates found

As of the 16th of February 2022, private and public events can be held and attended without Corona protection measures in place or COVID certificates required. There are no restrictions on private gatherings, though public gatherings with audience still have a cap of 1000 people. The same rules for entering Switzerland apply to entering Liechtenstein. You may only enter if you are fully vaccinated, with the final vaccine dose having been delivered in the past 270 days; if you are fully vaccinated, no negative test or entry form is required. If you are not fully vaccinated, and are not an EU, Swiss, or Liechtenstein national, or holder of a residency permit, you may not enter the country.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305134613/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/de/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305134849/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/liechtenstein/entry-requirements

It is possible to apply for and receive short-time work compensation due to the economic consequences of the pandemic. This is officially in place until the end of March 2022, with the possibility of extension until June 2022. The test centre in Vaduz in the Marktplatzgarage is open daily from 14:00 to 17:00. No appointment is necessary, and results are available within 24-36 hours. The test if free if you have health insurance, and you do not have to be symptomatic to order one.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305133605/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220319220909/https://www.regierung.li/coronavirus

The test centre in Vaduz in the Marktplatzgarage is open daily from 14:00 to 17:00. No appointment is necessary, and results are available within 24-36 hours. The test if free if you have health insurance, and you do not have to be symptomatic to order one.  Source: https://archive.ph/eS2Kd & https://archive.ph/bTxvL

The test centre in Vaduz in the Marktplatzgarage is open daily from 14:00 to 17:00. No appointment is necessary, and results are available within 24-36 hours. The test if free if you have health insurance, and you do not have to be symptomatic to order one. Note that this service only offers PCR tests and not rapid antigen tests - these can be made by appointment in some pharmacies and with some doctors  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220413172522/https://www.regierung.li/coronavirus

Upon testing positive, people are asked to list their contacts whenever possible for "traceability purposes".  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20220305133605/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/
Upon testing positive, people are asked to list their contacts whenever possible for "traceability purposes".  Source:  https://archive.ph/bTxvL
Active contact tracing has been discontinued as of April 1st 2022.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220413180022/https://www.regierung.li/de/mitteilungen/228890/?typ=content&nid=11076

For all over 12, face masks are required on public transport and in healthcare facilities.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220319221552/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/
For all over 12, face masks are required on public transport and in healthcare facilities.  Source: https://archive.ph/bTxvL

Masks are no longer legally required on public transport or any other public place. Individual institutions, including healthcare facilities and nursing homes, can continue to impose a mask requirement at their own discretion.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220413173331/https://www.regierung.li/de/mitteilungen/228884/?typ=content&nid=11076 & http://web.archive.org/web/20220413172743/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/

Residents aged 5 and over can register for vaccination, with booster vaccines available for all those 12 and over. The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are being used. Before meeting someone who is high risk, including the elderly, it is recommended that a PCR or rapid antigen test is taken. Those who wish to particularly protect themselves are advised to limit close contact with others. Masks are required in retirement and nursing homes by guests.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305142009/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/so-schuetzen-wir-uns.html & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305142534/https://www.gesetze.li/chrono/2022018000

PCR or antigen tests recommended on 3rd day of arrivial latest and no self-isolation if vaccinated and/or from European Economic Area. Vaccine proof is required. Per changes on March 1st, individuals attending school are no longer required to have covid passport or overload certificate. (Rules still apply to adults over the age of 18 attending school.)  However, educators and staff are required to have vaccination certificate.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220321164223/https://covid19.gov.lv/aktualites/nosacijumi-pakalpojumu-sniegsanai-un-tirdzniecibai-no-1-marta  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152321/https://covid19.gov.lv/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ka-drosi-rikoties/covid-19-izplatibas-ierobezosanas-pasakumi  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152408/https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates-par-covid-19

Employees involved in the study process must have a vaccination or recovery certificate. Pupils and students at all levels can study in person without any preconditions or facemasks wearing.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220402112148/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Some sectors require the vaccine, such as healthcare providers, long-erm social care services, prison staff, people who provide public services with direct contact with recipient of services.  There is a general recommendation to work from home if possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321164223/https://covid19.gov.lv/aktualites/nosacijumi-pakalpojumu-sniegsanai-un-tirdzniecibai-no-1-marta  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152321/https://covid19.gov.lv/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ka-drosi-rikoties/covid-19-izplatibas-ierobezosanas-pasakumi  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152408/https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates-par-covid-19

Persons without a vaccination or recovery certificate can perform the work on-site.  The following persons must have a primary vaccination or recovery certificate:      - Employees of medical institutions in direct contact with patients,  Employees of educational institutions in direct contact with learners.  Remote work is recommended.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402112148/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Per the updated mandate on March 1st, both vaccinated and unvaccinated can attend indoor/outdoor events with a medical grade facemask, with a maximum of 3000 people.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152321/https://covid19.gov.lv/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ka-drosi-rikoties/covid-19-izplatibas-ierobezosanas-pasakumi  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152408/https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates-par-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321153038/https://www.vmnvd.gov.lv/lv/sertifikatu-veidi-un-izmantosana

All cultural sites are accessible to everyone without space restrictions and other safety requirements.  There are no restrictions on organising events.  Event organisers and service providers have the right to set epidemiological safety requirements when assessing risks.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402112148/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

All persons are restricted to up to 50 people for private events and up to 250 people for baptisms, weddings and funerals.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152321/https://covid19.gov.lv/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ka-drosi-rikoties/covid-19-izplatibas-ierobezosanas-pasakumi  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152408/https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates-par-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321153038/https://www.vmnvd.gov.lv/lv/sertifikatu-veidi-un-izmantosana
There are no restrictions on the number of people gathering.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402112148/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Medical grade or respirators without valve are required on public transportation.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152321/https://covid19.gov.lv/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ka-drosi-rikoties/covid-19-izplatibas-ierobezosanas-pasakumi  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152408/https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates-par-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321153038/https://www.vmnvd.gov.lv/lv/sertifikatu-veidi-un-izmantosana
https://web.archive.org/web/20220402112148/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

18/3/22  Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220317052425/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

18/3/22  No change until 31st March 2022    You are not quarantined if your antigen or PCR test is negative  and you meet one of the following conditions :    you are vaccinated with the full vaccination course:  a vaccine that is authorized in the European Union or is included in the list of vaccine equivalents authorized for marketing in the territory of the Republic of Poland, kept by the National Institute of Public Health PZH - National Research Institute,  14 days have elapsed since the administration of the last dose of vaccination (counted from the day following the administration of the last dose),  vaccination is certified by the EU COVID Certificate or another document in Polish or English confirming the vaccination.  You have been infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus (you are the so-called healer):  not later than 6 months before the day of crossing the PR border,  you have a document that confirms the presence of the disease, issued in Polish or English, including the EU COVID Certificate .  You are subject to other exemptions listed in Â§ 3 of the Regulation of the Council of Ministers of May 6, 2021 on the establishment of certain restrictions, orders and bans in connection with the occurrence of an epidemic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220308150404/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-spoza-strefy-schengen

1/4/22  From March 28, the obligation to undergo quarantine after crossing the border will be abolished  From March 28, 2022, pursuant to the provisions of the Regulation of the Council of Ministers of March 25, 2022 on the establishment of certain restrictions, orders and bans in connection with an epidemic (Journal of Laws, item 673), all travel restrictions are lifted. The Republic of Poland, which means that there is no longer an obligation to:    - showing vaccination certificates when crossing the border,    - testing for SARS-CoV-2,    - taking the so-called incoming quarantine.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/granice-i-ruch-miedzynarodowy

18/3/22  No change    Change in policy. Test are now available for anyone at a pharmacy without prior registration    How to get a coronavirus test at a pharmacy  No signups, no long waiting times and free of charge - now you can get tested at the pharmacy if you are concerned that you have the coronavirus. Check in which pharmacies near you can make it and on what terms!    In the pharmacy, you can do an antigen test:    without prior registration;  free;  unlimited - as many times as you need,  fast - the result after only a dozen or so minutes!  How to do it  Come to the pharmacy where the tests are performed - but be careful! Not every pharmacy participates in the program. Find out where the nearest pharmacy that runs the tests is .  The pharmacist will take a swab.  After a dozen or so minutes, you will receive the result and the pharmacist will enter it in the system.  You can also find information about the result on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .  Test results  If your score is:    negative - you will receive the EU COVID Certificate after the antigen test (valid for 48 hours),  positive - you will start home insulation .  Information on how long your isolation will last and certificates can be found on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .    Attention! Antigen tests are carried out in pharmacies. After a negative antigen test result, you can generate an EU COVID Certificate (UCC), but it will only be valid for 48 hours .    If you fall ill with the coronavirus and confirm the disease with the antigen test, you will not get the convalescent status and the EU COVID Certificate after 10 days!    Recover status confirmed by UCC can only be obtained after confirming the disease with  a PCR test performed at the collection point . Check how to sign up for a test at a download point .      https://web.archive.org/web/20220204154012/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zapisz-sie-na-test-na-koronawirusa

1/4/22  From April 1, 2022, the rules for ordering and performing coronavirus tests will change.  Your doctor will decide to refer you for a coronavirus test based on an assessment of your health, including symptoms that may indicate COVID-19. .  If a GP decides to test a patient with disturbing symptoms, it will be a rapid antigen test. The test result is known after a few or several minutes. The test will be free for the patient.  A PCR test may be ordered by your doctor prior to admission to hospital if deemed necessary. The PCR test will be used in the event of definitive confirmation or exclusion of whether the symptoms of respiratory tract infections with which the patient entered the hospital are caused by the coronavirus.  In the case of a positive SARS-CoV-2 test result, the doctor recommends self-isolation (sick leave) until symptoms disappear. Just like any infectious disease, such as the flu.  The length of the sick leave depends on the doctor (minimum 7 days recommended), depending on the patient's condition, risk factors for the severe course of the COVID-19 disease (e.g. lack of vaccination against COVID-19, advanced age, chronic diseases, e.g. diabetes) and high risk the occurrence of complications.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zapisz-sie-na-test-na-koronawirusa

18/3/22  No change  Limited contact tracing in place.    I was in close contact with a person who tested positive. Should I report it somewhere?  If you are in close contact with a person infected with the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus (this person has obtained a confirmed, positive PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infection), report this fact to the sanitary inspection. Use the online form: Application for quarantine or isolation by the Sanepid.    If you have questions about quarantine, please call the hotline to contact the sanitary inspection : +48 22 25 00 115. The  hotline is open 24 hours a day.    Important! If you know you have been in close contact with an infected or sick person, stay home - even if you have not yet decided to quarantine, and you are feeling well. Avoid contact with other people. You can infect them if you find out that you are infected. If this is not possible, use all required personal protective equipment.    Attention! If you have been vaccinated for COVID-19, you will not be placed in quarantine. The rule applies from December 28, 2020.    However, from December 15, family  members of people suffering from COVID19 must undergo a coronavirus test, regardless of the certificate they have.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

The  hotline is open 24 hours a day.    Important! If you have been vaccinated for COVID-19, you will not be placed in quarantine. The rule applies from December 28, 2020.    However, from December 15, family  members of people suffering from COVID19 must undergo a coronavirus test, regardless of the certificate they have.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

1/4/22  I was in close contact with a person who tested positive. Should I report it somewhere?  Not. The so-called quarantine from contact.     Important! If you know that you have had close contact with an infected or sick person and you develop symptoms - take the test .    A test referral means an automatic quarantine that will end if you test negative. Quarantine does not apply to tests performed privately. A positive test result always requires isolation for 7 days.    Check the test result in the Internet Patient Account !    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/pytania-i-odpowiedzi

18/3/22  Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220317052425/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

1/4/22  Social distance and face masks  From Monday (March 28, 2022) the obligation to wear masks has been abolished.    The exception applies to medical entities and pharmacies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220328131536/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

18/3/22  No Change  We want as many people as possible to receive the preparation against Covid-19 in the shortest possible time. It is in the interest of all of us - the vaccine offers a real chance of recovery.    E-referral    This is the document that entitles you to have the vaccine. In most cases, it is generated automatically for people who can sign up for a vaccination. Only in some cases do patients report to the doctor for this document. This happens when a given person does not have a PESEL number, or in the case of specific patients with the indicated diseases - they are informed about it.    The e-referral is valid for 90 days, but don't hesitate. If you have the opportunity, sign up for the vaccination now!    Registration for vaccination    Anyone who has an e-referral can sign up for a vaccination. There are several ways to do this:    call the helpline 989,  register online via e-Registration,  send an SMS saying SzczepimySie to the number 880 333 333,  sign up directly at the vaccination point (preferably by phone),  use the drive-thru point .     https://web.archive.org/web/20220127030346/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/jak-sie--zaszczepic

1/4/22  No change  How to get vaccinated?  The pass for vaccination is e-referral. Currently, children from 5 years of age can get vaccinated. There are a few basic rules to follow right before vaccination. Read on for details.    We want as many people as possible to receive the preparation against Covid-19 in the shortest possible time. It is in the interest of all of us - the vaccine offers a real chance of recovery.    E-referral    This is the document that entitles you to have the vaccine. In most cases, it is generated automatically for people who can sign up for a vaccination. Only in some cases do patients report to the doctor for this document. This happens when a given person does not have a PESEL number, or in the case of specific patients with the indicated diseases - they are informed about it.    The e-referral is valid for 90 days, but don't hesitate. If you have the opportunity, sign up for the vaccination now!    Registration for vaccination    Anyone who has an e-referral can sign up for a vaccination. There are several ways to do this:    call the helpline 989,  register online via e-Registration,  send an SMS saying SzczepimySie to the number 880 333 333,  mojeIKP - mobile application,  sign up directly at the vaccination point (preferably by phone),  use the drive-thru point .     Register for vaccination - find out the details    How to prepare for vaccinations *?    Get enough sleep before vaccination - sleep has a positive effect on the immune system.  Limit alcohol - a few days before vaccination, but also after taking the preparation, reduce the amount, and preferably do not consume alcohol at all.  Be physically active before vaccination - exercise improves your body's performance.  You do not need to fast before having the vaccine - eat all meals as normal on the day of vaccination.  Do not stop taking the medications you regularly take on your own - consult your doctor.  Carefully complete the pre-vaccination questionnaire - you will be asked to complete a medical questionnaire before taking the preparation. Don't withhold any information!  Wait after vaccination at the vaccination site of min . 15 minutes - it's for your safety.  Do not be afraid of NOP - it is short for undesirable vaccine reactions. They are mostly mild and rare. It may happen that after receiving the vaccine you will have, for example, redness at the injection site or a mild fever. These symptoms should disappear within 1-3 days. If you are more uncomfortable, you can take an anti-pyretic drug after vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/jak-sie--zaszczepic

There are a few basic rules to follow right before vaccination. Read on for details.    We want as many people as possible to receive the preparation against Covid-19 in the shortest possible time. It is in the interest of all of us - the vaccine offers a real chance of recovery.    E-referral    This is the document that entitles you to have the vaccine. In most cases, it is generated automatically for people who can sign up for a vaccination. Only in some cases do patients report to the doctor for this document. This happens when a given person does not have a PESEL number, or in the case of specific patients with the indicated diseases - they are informed about it.    The e-referral is valid for 90 days, but don't hesitate. If you have the opportunity, sign up for the vaccination now!    Registration for vaccination    Anyone who has an e-referral can sign up for a vaccination. There are several ways to do this:    call the helpline 989,  register online via e-Registration,  send an SMS saying SzczepimySie to the number 880 333 333,  mojeIKP - mobile application,  sign up directly at the vaccination point (preferably by phone),  use the drive-thru point .     Register for vaccination - find out the details    How to prepare for vaccinations *?    Get enough sleep before vaccination - sleep has a positive effect on the immune system.  Limit alcohol - a few days before vaccination, but also after taking the preparation, reduce the amount, and preferably do not consume alcohol at all.  Be physically active before vaccination - exercise improves your body's performance.  You do not need to fast before having the vaccine - eat all meals as normal on the day of vaccination.  Do not stop taking the medications you regularly take on your own - consult your doctor.  Carefully complete the pre-vaccination questionnaire - you will be asked to complete a medical questionnaire before taking the preparation. Don't withhold any information!  Wait after vaccination at the vaccination site of min . 15 minutes - it's for your safety.  Do not be afraid of NOP - it is short for undesirable vaccine reactions. They are mostly mild and rare. It may happen that after receiving the vaccine you will have, for example, redness at the injection site or a mild fever. These symptoms should disappear within 1-3 days. If you are more uncomfortable, you can take an anti-pyretic drug after vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/jak-sie--zaszczepic
Free
Free

18/3/22  Are vaccinations voluntary?  Vaccination is voluntary, except for healthcare professionals, pharmacists, medical students and healthcare professionals who must be fully vaccinated by March 1, 2022. We encourage other people to vaccinate against COVID-19. The more people get vaccinated, the more effective protection against the coronavirus will be.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220304084051/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/pytania-i-odpowiedzi

11.	The learning and teaching process in pre-school and daycare institutions shall take place according to the recommendations for pre-school institutions of NIPHK dated 20.01.2022.      12.	The learning and teaching process in all pre-university education institutions of all levels, as well as in daycare centres shall take place in accordance with the MEST Guidelines for the organization of the educational process in the conditions of the Covid-19 pandemic. The task forces of the educational institutions decide on the application of scenarios for the organization of the teaching process, depending on the situation in the institution and in the classrooms.    13.	The teaching process in public and private institutions of higher education, as well as in vocational and non-formal education institutions, can take place with physical presence provided that groups over 50 people are accommodated in no more than 50% of the space.     14.	Students must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2 in order to be allowed registration to the dormitory.    15.	Students in public and private university institutions must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the building of the institution.    16.	Staff in all public and private institutions of all levels of education, including preschool and daycare institutions, must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the institution building.     17.	The highest administrative officer, or equivalent position, of each institution according to points 14, 15 and 16, is obliged by decision to appoint one or more responsible persons who will control the possession of any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315002518/https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/https:/msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

F. [Restriction of public and private gatherings]     19.	Unless otherwise specified in this Decision, indoor gatherings of up to 50% of capacities (workshops, meetings, seminars, trainings or other gatherings) are allowed. Except those under the age of 12, participants are obliged to possess any of the evidence mentioned in points 19.1 to 19.4 in order to be allowed to enter these premises, and the organizer is obliged to provide a physical distance of one (1) meter between persons and check the relevant evidence, such as:      19.1	Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine against COVID-19;  19.2	Persons with medical evidence issued by the specialist doctor of the respective field verifying that they have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination must present the negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, which should not be older than 48 hours;  19.3	Single dose vaccination certificate, not older than one (1) month.  19.4	Evidence that the person has recovered from COVID-19 in the last 90 days (positive RT-PCR test issued in the last 21â90 days).    20.	Meetings of the Assembly and Government are allowed regardless of the number of persons, respecting the wearing of masks and maintaining the physical distance of 1 (one) meter between persons.      21.	The Emergency Operational Centre of the Ministry of Health may issue a special permit, exceeding 50% of capacities, for events of special importance in the function of public interest.    22.	Outdoor gatherings and cultural events are allowed. The organizer is obliged to ensure the observation of measures, including the maintenance of a physical distance of 1 meter between persons and the presentation of evidence recorded in points 19.1 to 19.4, except participants under the age of 12, as well as the wearing of masks.    23.	Religious ceremonies and rites are allowed to carry out their activity up to 50% of the utilizing capacity, provided that they possess any of the evidence according to points 19.1 to 19.4 in order to be allowed to enter the indoor spaces, in accordance with the relevant instruction, except participants under the age of 12.    https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

Entry and Exit Requirements  Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? Yes  Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? Varies (see below)  As of March 1, 2022, every person who enters Kosovo must produce one of the following:  Full vaccination certificate with two (2) doses (or a single-dose of Janssen vaccine) not exceeding more than 12 months after receiving the last dose;  Vaccination certificate with a single dose, together with a negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours;  Evidence that the person has recovered from COVID-19 in the last 90 days (positive RT-PCR test issued in the last 21â90 days);  Evidence that the person has received the third / booster dose;  Evidence of negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours;  This requirement does not apply to children under the age of 12. Children from 12 to 16 years of age must have a negative RT-PCR test not older than 48 hours.    Airlines, transit points, and destination countries impose a patchwork of different testing requirements and airlines may refuse boarding for some passengers (including U.S. citizens and Kosovo residents). Airlines have the sole authority to decide who they allow to board their aircraft. Generally, pre-travel testing is recommended.  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes  The Pristina International Airport is open to travelers.  Check with the airlines, airports, and the U.S. Embassies located in your countries of transit to verify entry/exit requirements and be aware that they change frequently.    Quarantine Information  Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? Yes â self quarantine.  Citizens of the Republic of Kosovo, as well as persons with temporary or permanent resident permits, who enter the Republic of Kosovo and do not possess the evidence required above and seek to enter the country are obliged to respect home quarantine for a period of seven (7) days from the entry into the territory of the Republic of Kosovo.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

esting available across Kosovo    COVID-19 Testing  Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Kosovo? Yes  There are PCR and rapid antigen tests available from several private labs in Pristina and major towns in Kosovo.  The main public hospital in Pristina, the University Clinical Center of Kosovo (UCCK), provides free travel testing without a referral although availability and scheduling depend on demand.  Are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Turn-around time for results from the private clinics vary from several hours to 24 hours and are available via email and hard copy. Results from UCCK are reportedly available within 24 hours, but it is best to check with them due to expected higher demand.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html   If you are in Kosovo and have COVID-19 related questions, are symptomatic, or need information regarding testing, please call toll free 038 200 80 800, or dial 194.  The U.S. Embassy does not endorse or recommend any particular healthcare provider, but below is a list of clinics and hospitals who are providing tests. Testing available across Kosovo    COVID-19 Testing  Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Kosovo? Yes  There are PCR and rapid antigen tests available from several private labs in Pristina and major towns in Kosovo.  The main public hospital in Pristina, the University Clinical Center of Kosovo (UCCK), provides free travel testing without a referral although availability and scheduling depend on demand.  Are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Turn-around time for results from the private clinics vary from several hours to 24 hours and are available via email and hard copy. Results from UCCK are reportedly available within 24 hours, but it is best to check with them due to expected higher demand.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html   If you are in Kosovo and have COVID-19 related questions, are symptomatic, or need information regarding testing, please call toll free 038 200 80 800, or dial 194.  The U.S. Embassy does not endorse or recommend any particular healthcare provider, but below is a list of clinics and hospitals who are providing tests. Please contact them directly for details on location, tests offered, and pricing:  Medical and Laboratory Services SHPK, +383 48 111 000 or +383 38 600 188  Prolab, +383 49 789 410  Olive Lab, +383 38 720 055, +383 49 520 056  UBT â Laboratori I Mikrobiologis e Klinike, + 383 46 500 777, +383 46 500 888  Avicena, +383 49 825 555  UCCK â University Clinical Center Kosovo (public hospital), +381 38 500 600    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101164843/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

Staff in all public and private institutions of all levels of education, including  preschool and daycare institutions, must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point  4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the institution building.     Students must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2 in order to be  allowed registration to the dormitory    The highest administrative officer, or equivalent position, of public, private institutions,  as well as other entities, is obliged to appoint one or more responsible persons who will  control the possession of any of the evidence mentioned in points 4.1 to 4.2.     All employees of public institutions, central and local public enterprises, private  businesses, organizations, as well as other entities, must possess one of the following  evidence, in order to be allowed to enter the work premises:    4.1 Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine  against COVID-19;  4.2 Persons with medical evidence from a specialist in the relevant field that they  have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination, must possess a  negative RT-PCR test for COVID 19 not older than one week;

The Authorities of the Republic of San Marino issued Decree-Law no. 3 of 14 January 2022 - Strengthening of provisions to avoid the spread of the COVID-19 virus. The provisions of the aforementioned Decree-Law, ratified by Decree-Law no. 6 of 21 January 2022, unless otherwise provided for, shall apply until the end of the health emergency, which is currently extended until 30 April 2022.         Entry into the Republic of San Marino, for those coming from countries other than Italy and the Vatican City, or who have stayed outside these two countries in the previous 14 days, is permitted on presentation of the following documents:         A certificate of vaccination against SARS-CoV-2* or a certificate of recovery from SARS-CoV-2 within the previous six months. This certificate may be in paper or digital form;  Or    A negative coronavirus test certificate following a molecular or antigenic swab taken no later than 48 hours before entry and in any case in accordance with the health protocols in force in the Republic of San Marino. Any molecular swab taken within 48 hours prior to entry into the territory of the Italian Republic is considered valid for those who do not fall within the cases referred to in letter a) above.        Children under ten years of age are exempt from submitting the certificates referred to in letters a) and b).    https://web.archive.org/web/2021*/https://www.esteri.sm/pub2/EsteriSM/en/Covid/Covid.html

Workers in healthcare and social care institutions and in prisons are required to comply by the "RVT - recovered, vaccinated, or tested" rule to enter workplaces. This has been relaxed, with previously more places of work having to abide by this rule.  - Recovery must be proved via a positive PCR result in the last 180 days  - An individual is considered vaccinated from the day of their vaccination, and onwards.  - Tests can either be in the form of a rapid antigen test conducted in the last 48 hours or a PCR test conducted in the last 72 hours.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163253/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

Workers in healthcare and social protection sectors (including hospitals, social care institutions and prisons) are required to comply by the "RVT - recovered, vaccinated, or tested" rule to enter workplaces. This has been relaxed, with previously more places of work having to abide by this rule.  - Recovery must be proved via a positive PCR result in the last 180 days  - An individual is considered vaccinated from the day of their vaccination, and onwards.  - Tests can either be in the form of a rapid antigen test conducted in the last 48 hours or a PCR test conducted in the last 72 hours.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220406141347/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

All travellers arriving in Slovenia will no longer be required to present proof of vaccination or a negative COVID-19 test. All travellers arriving in Slovenia must continue to complete the Digital Passenger Locator Form 24 hours before arrival, if entering via an airport or a ferry terminal. The form is not required if entering overland at a border crossing.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309171748/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/entry-requirements & http://web.archive.org/web/20220309171842/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/border-crossing/

Free testing with a rapid antigen test and a rapid antigen test for self-testing is abolished. The government budget will only pay for testing with a rapid antigen test for activities where this is still required. Such activities include:  - Users of hospital and other healthcare services   - Persons who wish to discontinue their self-isolation between days 7 and 10 after testing positive  - Persons with proof of a positive rapid-antigen self-test result   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163253/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163718/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

Surgical mask II or IIR or a FFP2 or a FFP3 mask are mandatory in all closed public spaces and on public transport. Vaccines are available for those age 12 and older. AstraZeneca, Moderna, and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines are all available. Vaccination is free of charge and is provided to all those who have permanent or temporary residence in the Republic of Slovenia, regardless of whether they are insured.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309181259/https://www.gov.si/teme/koronavirus-sars-cov-2/cepljenje-proti-covid-19/

AstraZeneca, Moderna, and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines are available for those age 12 and older. The Comirnaty 10 Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is available to all children aged 5-11; this is especially recommended in children who are immunocompromised.  Vaccination is free of charge and is provided to all those who have permanent or temporary residence in the Republic of Slovenia, regardless of whether they are insured.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309181259/https://www.gov.si/teme/koronavirus-sars-cov-2/cepljenje-proti-covid-19/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220406143814/https://www.nijz.si/sl/cepljenje-proti-covid-19-za-strokovno-javnost

1st April 2022 onwards, the remaining official recommendations will be removed or adapted to the rate of transmission, the burden on health care services, and vaccination rates at that time. After that, the vaccination recommendation will remain in place, along with specific recommendations for health service and care environments.    The new measures include the removal of participants limits in public gatherings and events, abolishing maximum group sizes in eating and drinking establishments, shopping centers, private gatherings and tournaments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319142922/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/travelling-to-sweden-entry-rules-restrictions-explained/
